user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtList_Create:
```c
UtListHead_t *UtList_Create(uint32 NumTags)
{
    struct ListAllocator
    {
        UtListHead_t Head;
        UtListNode_t Tags[];
    };
    struct ListAllocator *NewList;
    UtListNode_t *        TagHead;
    size_t                ActualSize;
    uint32                i;

    ActualSize = sizeof(struct ListAllocator) + (sizeof(UtListNode_t) * NumTags);
    NewList    = (struct ListAllocator *)malloc(ActualSize);

    memset(NewList, 0, ActualSize);

    NewList->Head.Tags         = NewList->Tags;
    NewList->Head.NumberOfTags = NumTags;

    for (i = 0; i < NumTags; ++i)
    {
        TagHead       = &NewList->Head.Tags[i];
        TagHead->Tag  = i;
        TagHead->Next = TagHead;
        TagHead->Prev = TagHead;
    }

    return &NewList->Head;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UtList_Create:
void UtTest_EarlyInit(void)
{
    /*
     * Reset the test global variables, just in case.
     */
    memset(&UtAssert_Global, 0, sizeof(UtAssert_Global));
    UtAssert_Global.DataBasePtr = UtList_Create(UTASSERT_GROUP_MAX);
}
...
void OS_Application_Startup(void)
{
    int32 Status;

    Status = OS_API_Init();
    if (Status != OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        BSP_DEBUG("Error: OS_API_Init() failed with status=%d\n", (int)Status);
        OS_ApplicationExit(Status);
    }
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: No function in the provided code calls itself, either directly or indirectly, based on the fragments shown. UtList_Create does not contain any calls to UtList_Create (or to any other project function) — it only calls standard library functions malloc and memset. The loop initializes node pointers (TagHead->Next = TagHead; TagHead->Prev = TagHead;) which are self-referential pointer assignments but are not function calls and therefore not recursion. The only caller shown, UtTest_EarlyInit, calls UtList_Create (one-way); there is no evidence in the provided code that UtList_Create calls back into UtTest_EarlyInit or any other function that would form a recursion cycle. The nested struct definition inside UtList_Create and the use of standard library functions do not introduce recursion by themselves. If there are additional, unshown functions or nonstandard overrides (e.g., custom malloc/memset wrappers) elsewhere in the codebase that call UtList_Create, those would need to be inspected, but no such evidence exists in the supplied fragments.
